pullRequest.body:
This PR defines `CFC.nnrpow`, `CFC.sqrt` and `CFC.rpow` based on the continuous functional calculus. We define two separate versions `CFC.nnrpow` (based on the non-unital calculus) and `CFC.rpow` (unital) due to what happens at 0. Since `NNReal.rpow 0 0 = 1`, this means that this function does not map zero to zero when the exponent
is zero, and hence `CFC.nnrpow a 0 = 0` whereas `CFC.rpow a 0 = 1`.

---

if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

:v: dupuisf can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10421801308/job/28864844553)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10421801308/job/28864844277)

Please merge master, as I expect there may be some breakage. Also, now that #11092 is merged, it would be interesting to see if it helps at all without that "redeclaration" of the `fun_prop` attribute (although given our other testing, I doubt it). In any case:

bors d+
This isn't a thorough look, but I wanted to have a first pass.

This is all I have the time or energy for right now. I think there is some more to be cleaned up yet regarding automation. I think we're missing a few more `fun_prop` lemmas, or possibly even some continuity lemmas about `rpow` (the OG `NNReal.rpow` that is, not `CFC.rpow`).

Here's another set of simplifications by making appropriate `fun_prop` lemmas. As I said before, `fun_prop` is not perfect, but it's quite good overall, and if you learn not to lead it astray, then I think we can make it succeed most of the time.

Note: the `∨` I used in the statement is precisely to avoid leading it astray in this way. Both of those conditions should be relatively easy for a smart discharger like `aesop` to either succeed in one, or fail in both. And in the latter case, the result will likely not be true (or else it will require a much more sophisticated human-supplied argument).

(I'll probably have one last round of review after this.)

gah, more stuff! And some `fun_prop` problems. This is one of the first times I've really been bitten hard by it. It also makes me question whether the `NNReal.nnrpow` was really a true solution or it just got lucky from being defined close.

Please merge master, as I expect there may be some breakage. Also, now that #11092 is merged, it would be interesting to see if it helps at all without that "redeclaration" of the `fun_prop` attribute (although given our other testing, I doubt it). In any case:

bors d+
Is there a reason *not* to define a `Pow A ℝ≥0` instance for `CFC.rpowₙ`? I don't *think* it will cause elaboration problems.
I'm afraid that in the unital case both of them will apply, and then it'll be painful to distinguish `rpowₙ` from `rpow`.
Actually I just tried putting the `Pow A ℝ≥0` instance and it seems fine.
That's what I expected from the elaborator for pow. The type of the exponent tells it what to look for. It's the same reason we don't have issues with `Nat` and `Int` powers in groups.

I think calling it `nnrpow` is more suggestive, and aligns better with the actual definition. Feel free to disagree.
```suggestion
+ `CFC.nnrpow`: the `ℝ≥0` power function based on the non-unital CFC, i.e. `cfcₙ NNReal.rpow` composed with `(↑) : ℝ≥0 → ℝ`.
```
Yeah that sounds good actually.
It would be good to emphasize that the non-unital one only allows nonnegative exponents, and to explain why (among other things, it should allow both `Pow` instances without conflict).

I was planning to suggest that we should have a `Units` version of this, but I think what actually makes more sense is to have a `simp` lemma of the form `{a : Aˣ} : 0 ∉ spectrum R a`, if we don't already. (Obviously not for this PR, this is a note to self)
And also, we should figure out how to deal with strict positivity at some point.
I have a plan for that. In progress.

Since you already have the `0 ≤ a` assumption, you can get away with:
```suggestion
    {a : A} {x y : ℝ} (ha₁ : 0 ∉ spectrum ℝ≥0 a) (hx : x ≠ 0) (ha₂ : 0 ≤ a := by cfc_tac) :
```

I didn't say this before, but could have: since this is the `ℝ≥0`-spectrum, not including zero is equivalent to being positive.
```suggestion
lemma sqrt_rpow_of_spectrum_pos {a : A} {x : ℝ} (h : 0 ∉ spectrum ℝ≥0 a)
```
Fair enough.

```suggestion
lemma rpow_sqrt_of_spectrum_pos {a : A} {x : ℝ} (h : 0 ∉ spectrum ℝ≥0 a)
```
According to [Loogle](https://loogle.lean-lang.org/?q=Pow+%3FA+ℝ≥0), we don't have any others. If you still want to set it low, okay, but I think `50` is too low.

This `rw` was *extremely* slow (thank goodness for incremental compilation!). I spent a short amount of time debugging, and about an hour coming up with a solution. The issue seems to be the following: `fun_prop (disch := aesop)` succeeded, but was very slow. Moreover, it was clear `aesop` was doing some sort of lifting because `fun_prop` alone failed. So I figured, I'll add an `@[fun_prop]` lemma of the form `∀ y : ℝ≥0, Continuous fun x : ℝ≥0 ↦ x ^ (y : ℝ)` because then it will find this and we'll be set. That *did* allow `fun_prop` alone to succeed, but it was still slow. However, `apply Continuous.continuousOn; fun_prop` was instant. This suggested to me that `fun_prop` was going down some rabbit hole involving the coercion because too much was unfolded already. So, my solution is this: we add
```
namespace NNReal

noncomputable
abbrev nnrpow (a : ℝ≥0) (b : ℝ≥0) : ℝ≥0 := a ^ (b : ℝ)

-- maybe this could even be marked `@[simp]`
lemma nnrpow_def (a b : ℝ≥0) : nnrpow a b = a ^ (b : ℝ) := rfl

@[fun_prop]
lemma continuous_nnrpow_const (y : ℝ≥0) : Continuous (nnrpow · y) :=
  continuous_rpow_const zero_le_coe
	
@[aesop safe apply]
lemma nnrpow_zero {a : ℝ≥0} (ha : 0 < a) : nnrpow 0 a = 0 := by
  rw [nnrpow_def]; aesop

end NNReal
```
Then change the following def and lemma to:
```
noncomputable def nnrpow (a : A) (y : ℝ≥0) : A := cfcₙ (NNReal.nnrpow · y) a

lemma nnrpow_def {a : A} {y : ℝ≥0} : a ^ y = cfcₙ (NNReal.nnrpow · y) a := rfl
```
It is a bit interesting that `abbrev NNReal.nnrpow` is enough, but it seems to be. Indeed, this allows for the quite fast and nice proof of this lemma:
```suggestion
lemma nnrpow_add {a : A} {x y : ℝ≥0} (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y) :
    a ^ (x + y) = a ^ x * a ^ y := by
  simp only [nnrpow_def]
  rw [← cfcₙ_mul _ _ a]
  congr! 2 with z
  exact_mod_cast NNReal.rpow_add' z <| ne_of_gt (add_pos hx hy)
```
This suggestion requires adding `NNReal.nnrpow_def` to some of the `simp` calls elsewhere.

Thanks for doing that deep dive! There's also the simpler solution of just adding this lemma:
```lean
@[fun_prop]
lemma continuousOn_rpow_nnreal {y : ℝ≥0} {s : Set ℝ≥0} : ContinuousOn (fun x : ℝ≥0 => x ^ (y : ℝ)) s :=
  Continuous.continuousOn <| NNReal.continuous_rpow_const NNReal.zero_le_coe
```
I think I slightly prefer this option, both are a bit of a hack to get `fun_prop` to do things in the right order, and this is a bit less disruptive.

With the above suggestion, we get:
```suggestion
        rw [← cfcₙ_comp _ _ a]
        congr! 2 with u
        ext
        simp [NNReal.nnrpow_def, Real.rpow_mul]
```
and it's pretty fast.

also with the above:
```suggestion
  rw [nnrpow_def, rpow_def, cfcₙ_eq_cfc]
```

You can deal with all the `0` cases like this quickly:
```
    obtain (rfl | hx) := eq_zero_or_pos x <;> obtain (rfl | hx) := eq_zero_or_pos y
    all_goals try simp
```
By the way, I knew we had to have that lemma: `eq_zero_or_pos`, and it was found instantly with a quick [Loogle](https://loogle.lean-lang.org/?q=%3Fx+%3D+0+∨+0+<+%3Fx)

```suggestion
  rw [← cfc_pow_id (R := ℝ≥0) a n, rpow_def]
  congr
  simp
```

Many times you can just ask Lean to infer this instead of writing it out yourself. However, you *do* need to ask it to infer, or else the autoparams won't fire (or they'll fire with metavariables, which currently causes `fun_prop` to crash).
```suggestion
  rw [rpow_def, cfc_algebraMap ..]
```

It's not that the proof is super long, but we should definitely have this lemma, and we can make the automation work for us:
```lean
@[fun_prop]
theorem _root_.NNReal.continuousOn_rpow_const_compl_zero {r : ℝ} :
    ContinuousOn (fun z : ℝ≥0 => z ^ r) {0}ᶜ :=
  fun _ h => ContinuousAt.continuousWithinAt <| NNReal.continuousAt_rpow_const (.inl h)

-- even though this follows from `ContinuousOn.mono` and the previous lemma, we include it for
-- automation purposes with `fun_prop`, because the side goal `0 ∉ s ∨ 0 ≤ r` is often easy to check
@[fun_prop]
theorem _root_.NNReal.continuousOn_rpow_const {r : ℝ} {s : Set ℝ≥0}
    (h : 0 ∉ s ∨ 0 ≤ r) : ContinuousOn (fun z : ℝ≥0 => z ^ r) s :=
  h.elim (fun _ ↦ ContinuousOn.mono (s := {0}ᶜ) (by fun_prop) (by aesop))
    (NNReal.continuous_rpow_const · |>.continuousOn)
```
and then we get:
```suggestion
  rw [← cfc_mul _ _ a]
```

With the above:
```suggestion
  rw [← cfc_comp _ _ a]
```

With the above
```suggestion
  rw [← cfc_comp _ _ a]
```

We have a variant lemma for this:
```suggestion
  simp only [rpow_def, NNReal.coe_one, NNReal.rpow_eq_pow, NNReal.rpow_one, cfc_id' ℝ≥0 a]
```
Do we really need this? If you think so, that's fine.
Well, it's done so we might as well keep it!

There is something a bit unfortunate. We (unsurprisingly, perhaps), have a `Pow ℝ ℝ` instance. This means that creating a `ContinuousFunctionalCalculus ℝ (IsSelfAdjoint : ℝ → Prop)` would create diamonds, which is ... annoying. For now, of course we can just avoid creating such an instance, but at some point we'll surely want to view `ℝ` itself as a real C⋆-algebra, at which point all of a sudden this will be globally available. Therefore, looking ahead, we will probably need to scope this instance, although for now the lowered priority is fine.

Or maybe we can make `Pow ℝ ℝ` the default instance so that this one never triggers in that case? Is that possible? However we deal with this (a) it can wait, (b) please add a note about this issue here, (c) and one on the docstring for the instance.
Yeah, that's what I had in mind when I wrote about "other instances when they are available" in the docstring.

:tada: :heart: :+1: You may not know this (or perhaps you do), but for the longest time, this was my litmus test for whether the design of the continuous functional calculus API was the best one: does it make defining the square root of a nonnegative element in a non-unital C⋆-algebra, and proving it's basic properties (`sqrt_mul_sqrt_self`, `mul_sqrt_self`) trivial. And this certainly succeeds on that front.

Of course, I had already verified that this was possible, but it's just so nice to see it going into Mathlib.
I think it's finally time for me to get the `ppow` branch ready for merging. Using `ℝ≥0` powers is not too sustainable long term, but it's fine for now.
In this and the next two, `a` should be explicit (so that you can either supply it or get Lean to infer it so that the autoparam fires).

A few things it would be nice to have prior to ending the `nnrpow` section and moving on to square roots:
```
lemma nnrpow_nnrpow_inv [UniqueNonUnitalContinuousFunctionalCalculus ℝ≥0 A]
    (a : A) {x : ℝ≥0} (hx : x ≠ 0) (ha : 0 ≤ a := by cfc_tac) : (a ^ x) ^ x⁻¹ = a := by
  simp [mul_inv_cancel hx, nnrpow_one ha]

lemma nnrpow_inv_nnrpow [UniqueNonUnitalContinuousFunctionalCalculus ℝ≥0 A]
    (a : A) {x : ℝ≥0} (hx : x ≠ 0) (ha : 0 ≤ a := by cfc_tac) : (a ^ x⁻¹) ^ x = a := by
  simp [inv_mul_cancel hx, nnrpow_one ha]

lemma nnrpow_inv_eq [UniqueNonUnitalContinuousFunctionalCalculus ℝ≥0 A]
    (a b : A) {x : ℝ≥0} (hx : x ≠ 0) (ha : 0 ≤ a := by cfc_tac) (hb : 0 ≤ b := by cfc_tac) :
    a ^ x⁻¹ = b ↔ b ^ x = a :=
  ⟨fun h ↦ nnrpow_inv_nnrpow a hx ▸ congr($(h) ^ x).symm,
    fun h ↦ nnrpow_nnrpow_inv b hx ▸ congr($(h) ^ x⁻¹).symm⟩
```

likewise, it would be nice to add these:
```
lemma mul_self_eq {a b : A} (h : sqrt a = b) (ha : 0 ≤ a := by cfc_tac) :
    b * b = a :=
  h ▸ sqrt_mul_sqrt_self ha

lemma sqrt_unique {a b : A} (h : b * b = a) (hb : 0 ≤ b := by cfc_tac) :
    sqrt a = b :=
  h ▸ sqrt_mul_self b

lemma sqrt_eq_iff (a b : A) (ha : 0 ≤ a := by cfc_tac) (hb : 0 ≤ b := by cfc_tac) :
    sqrt a = b ↔ b * b = a :=
  ⟨(mul_self_eq ·), (sqrt_unique ·)⟩
```
And please fix any of the arguments in other declarations throughout the file where they should be explicit because of autoparams.
can you move these up to immediately after `rpow_def`?

I think this should be the default assumption here.
```suggestion
lemma rpow_add {a : A} {x y : ℝ} (ha : 0 ∉ spectrum ℝ≥0 a) :
```
and likewise for other lemmas, I think we can drop the hypothesis from the name.

somewhere in this section (maybe around here?) it would be nice to have at least these lemmas:
```
lemma rpow_mul_rpow_neg {a : A} (x : ℝ) (ha : 0 ∉ spectrum ℝ≥0 a)
    (ha' : 0 ≤ a := by cfc_tac) : a ^ x * a ^ (-x) = 1 := by
  rw [← rpow_add ha, add_right_neg, rpow_zero a]

lemma rpow_neg_mul_rpow {a : A} (x : ℝ) (ha : 0 ∉ spectrum ℝ≥0 a)
    (ha' : 0 ≤ a := by cfc_tac) : a ^ (-x) * a ^ x = 1 := by
  rw [← rpow_add ha, add_left_neg, rpow_zero a]

lemma inv_nonneg_of_nonneg (a : Aˣ) (ha : (0 : A) ≤ a := by cfc_tac) : (0 : A) ≤ a⁻¹ :=
  cfc_inv_id (R := ℝ≥0) a ▸ cfc_predicate _ (a : A)

lemma inv_nonneg (a : Aˣ)  : (0 : A) ≤ a⁻¹ ↔ (0 : A) ≤ a :=
  ⟨fun _ ↦ inv_inv a ▸ inv_nonneg_of_nonneg a⁻¹, fun _ ↦ inv_nonneg_of_nonneg a⟩

lemma rpow_neg_one_eq_inv (a : Aˣ) (ha : (0 : A) ≤ a := by cfc_tac) :
    a ^ (-1 : ℝ) = (↑a⁻¹ : A) := by
  refine a.inv_eq_of_mul_eq_one_left ?_ |>.symm
  simpa [rpow_one (a : A)] using rpow_neg_mul_rpow 1 (spectrum.zero_not_mem ℝ≥0 a.isUnit)

lemma rpow_neg {a : Aˣ} {x : ℝ} (ha' : (0 : A) ≤ a := by cfc_tac) :
    (a : A) ^ (-x) = (↑a⁻¹ : A) ^ x := by
  sorry -- possibly combine with the previous lemma and `rpow_rpow`

lemma rpow_intCast {a : Aˣ} {n : ℤ} (ha : (0 : A) ≤ a := by cfc_tac) :
    (a : A) ^ (n : ℝ) = (↑(a ^ n) : A) := by
  sorry -- follows easily from the previous lemma?
```

So I found out something *very* unfortunate here. The stuff that was supposed to be fast from this is slow! :fearful: It turns out that I had declared this and the attribute inside the file we were working on, so it was tried first and was fast. But at this location, it is tried later, and it's very slow (and seemingly for no good reason if you look at the trace). We desperately need to figure that out. Sorry this PR is turning out to be so much work, but I think we're learning some valuable lessons here, and fixing this kind of stuff now is important before we get in too deep.

By the way, you can tell it's just about the location where it's declared, because you can "redeclare" the attribute with `attribute [fun_prop] continuousOn_rpow_const` in the `CFC.rpow` file and it immediately becomes fast again, so it's definitely just the order in which things are tried. Although I have yet to understand why checking 8 `fun_prop` lemmas is slow. :face_with_diagonal_mouth:

I'm starting to think that `fun_prop` isn't the problem at all, *everything* is slow in this file (and pretty much every other file about the CFC), especially in the last section where we use both the unital and non-unital CFC. Try sorry-ing out a bunch of lemmas and you'll see what I mean: even then it's slow!

I think whatever is causing that problem is what is slowing down fun_prop: if it takes ~0.5s when it immediately picks the right lemma, it's not surprising that it takes 4s when it has to try 8 things.

:golf: You can just use the `NNReal.continuousOn_rpow_const` lemma we had here, plus some convenience lemmas concerning zero in the spectrum.
```suggestion
  suffices h₁ : ContinuousOn (fun z ↦ z ^ x) (Inv.inv '' (spectrum ℝ≥0 (a : A))) by
    rw [← cfc_inv_id (R := ℝ≥0) a, rpow_def, rpow_def,
        ← cfc_comp' (fun z => z ^ x) (Inv.inv : ℝ≥0 → ℝ≥0) (a : A) h₁]
    refine cfc_congr fun _ _ => ?_
    simp [NNReal.rpow_neg, NNReal.inv_rpow]
  refine NNReal.continuousOn_rpow_const (.inl ?_)
  rintro ⟨z, hz, hz'⟩
  exact spectrum.zero_not_mem ℝ≥0 a.isUnit <| inv_eq_zero.mp hz' ▸ hz
```
Can you move these into `Analysis.CStarAlgebra.ContinuousFunctionalCalculus.Unital`?
I did, but I couldn't generalize them properly because `OrderedSemifield` doesn't exist, so I left them specialized to `ℝ≥0`.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: define `rpow` and `sqrt` based on the continuous functional calculus

This isn't a thorough look, but I wanted to have a first pass.

This is all I have the time or energy for right now. I think there is some more to be cleaned up yet regarding automation. I think we're missing a few more `fun_prop` lemmas, or possibly even some continuity lemmas about `rpow` (the OG `NNReal.rpow` that is, not `CFC.rpow`).

Here's another set of simplifications by making appropriate `fun_prop` lemmas. As I said before, `fun_prop` is not perfect, but it's quite good overall, and if you learn not to lead it astray, then I think we can make it succeed most of the time.

Note: the `∨` I used in the statement is precisely to avoid leading it astray in this way. Both of those conditions should be relatively easy for a smart discharger like `aesop` to either succeed in one, or fail in both. And in the latter case, the result will likely not be true (or else it will require a much more sophisticated human-supplied argument).

(I'll probably have one last round of review after this.)

gah, more stuff! And some `fun_prop` problems. This is one of the first times I've really been bitten hard by it. It also makes me question whether the `NNReal.nnrpow` was really a true solution or it just got lucky from being defined close.

Please merge master, as I expect there may be some breakage. Also, now that #11092 is merged, it would be interesting to see if it helps at all without that "redeclaration" of the `fun_prop` attribute (although given our other testing, I doubt it). In any case:
